title: World's top ghostly getaways [Photos]
text:
Friday, October 23, 2015 07:00 AM EDT World's top ghostly getaways Previous Next 
Aokigahara Forest, Japan: This Mount Fuji-area forest has been given the unpleasant distinction of being a major destination for suicides, with more than 500 people having killed themselves here since the 1950s. Each year, police comb the forest to look for bodies. More than 100 dead bodies were discovered in 2004. The eerie stillness of the forest and ghosts of those caught in purgatory make this one of the most haunted locations in Asia. ( Wikipedia/ajari ) 
Changi Beach, Singapore: Believed to be the place where the Japanese killed Chinese soldiers during World War II, Changi Beach is haunted by headless bodies, deep graves and the sounds of wailing soldiers. (Shutterstock) 
Rose Hall Plantation, Jamaica: Annie Palmer, also known as the White Witch, was known as a mistress of voodoo and, it is said, killed three husbands at Rose Hall with her witchcraft when she became bored of them. Legend has it she was killed by a slave in the 1830s. Her tomb is located at Rose Hall and tourists visit to try to catch a glimpse of her wandering ghost. ( Wikipedia/Urban Walnut ) 
Fort Garry Hotel, Winnipeg: This hotel was built in 1913 by the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway and is considered to be one of the most haunted places in Canada. Cleaners have reported seeing objects fly from shelves and a woman who reportedly hung herself at the hotel crying in a corner. ( Wikipedia/Bobak Ha'Eri ) 
Plains of Abraham, Quebec City: The site of the 1759 Battle of the Plains of Abraham is haunted by apparitions who spook passersby. Reports of soldiers appearing on the field and in nearby tunnels are almost as creepy as reports one can smell canon sulphur wafting over the field at night. (Shutterstock) 
HI Ottawa Jail Hostel, Ottawa: This former prison was in operation for more than 100 years before being turned into a backpackers' haven. Guests have reported several strange happenings in the hostel, from clothing being scattered on the floor to doors without locks locking themselves to mysterious encounters with ghostly figures. (Courtesy HI Ottawa Jail Hostel) 
RMS Queen Mary, Long Beach, California: This retired ocean liner turned floating hotel hosts ghost tours to sate the appetites of tourists hungry for a glimpse of the famed hauntings on board. There have been 49 deaths on the ship and guests have reported seeing spirits walking the hallways, swimming in the first-class pool and even manning the engine room. (Shutterstock) 
Salem, Massachusetts: Book your ticket for Salem's Haunted Footsteps Ghost Tour soon! This tour shows you sites associated with the ghostly past of Salem, from the witch trials of 1692 to the art of cemeteries. Visit salemhistoricaltours.com. (Shutterstock) 
Savannah, Georgia: Named the most haunted place in the United States by the American Institute of Paranormal Psychology, Savannah is the ultimate place to embark on a guided ghost tour to discover the haunted hotels, homes and churches of this city. Savannah was founded in the 1700s and the ghosts of slaves and the first colonists are making sure they won't be forgotten. Spooky! (Shutterstock) 
Tower of London, England: This popular tourist attraction is also one of the most haunted buildings in the world. For the past 1,000 years, torture and executions have been carried out in the tower's dungeons. The most famous victim may be Anne Boleyn, one of the wives of Henry VIII. She was beheaded here in 1536 and some visitors say they have seen her ghost roaming the halls. (Shutterstock) Article
